case_vignette:
The patient is a 38-year-old Hispanic woman who presents with a 1-year history of a very pruritic rash over her interscapular area. On examination, she has a circular area of slightly hyperpigmented macules in the interscapular region. The patient complains of pruritus but no pain in the area of the rash. The patient has no other medical problems and has no systemic symptoms. She has no relevant social or family history and does not take any medications. The patient is a nonsmoker and does not drink alcohol. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. The patient's physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.
The patient is a 38-year-old Hispanic male who presents with a 1-year history of a very pruritic rash over his interscapular area. On examination, he has a circular area of slightly hyperpigmented macules in the interscapular region. The patient complains of pruritus but no pain in the area of the rash. The patient has no other medical problems and has no systemic symptoms. He has no relevant social or family history and does not take any medications. The patient is a nonsmoker and does not drink alcohol. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. The patient's physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.
The patient is a 38-year-old Hispanic individual who presents with a 1-year history of a very pruritic rash over the interscapular area. On examination, the individual has a circular area of slightly hyperpigmented macules in the interscapular region. The individual complains of pruritus but no pain in the area of the rash. The individual has no other medical problems and has no systemic symptoms. The individual has no relevant social or family history and does not take any medications. The individual is a nonsmoker and does not drink alcohol. The individual's vital signs are within normal limits. The individual's physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.
Note: The changes made were to remove the words "woman" and "male" and replace them with "individual". The word "his" was also removed and replaced with "the" to maintain grammatical correctness. The word "her" was also removed and replaced with "the" to maintain grammatical correctness. The word "he" was also removed and replaced with "the" to maintain grammatical correctness. The word "has" was also removed and replaced with "has"
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a very itchy rash over my upper back between the shoulder blades.
How long have you had this rash?
I've had the rash for about 1 year.
Have you noticed any changes in the appearance of the rash over this time?
The rash appears as a circular area of slightly darker colored spots.
Do you have any known allergies or previous skin conditions?
No, I don't have any known allergies or previous skin conditions.
Is there anyone in your family with a similar rash or a history of skin diseases?
No, there is no relevant family history of similar rashes or skin diseases.
Have you tried any medications or treatments for this rash? If so, what were they and did they provide any relief?
I have not taken any medications for this rash.
Final Diagnosis: Tinea versicolor
